item.title: Path-Connectedness in Topology
item.description: Definitions 1 Let’s call $X$ a topological space and let $C \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$. A continuous function $p : [0,1] \to X$ from initial point $p(0)$ to terminal point $p(1)$ is called a path. $\overline{p}(t) = p(1-t)$ is called the reverse path of $p$. If for every $a,b \in X$ there exists a path $p$ satisfying both $p(0) = a$ and $p(1) = b$, then $X$ is called a path-connected space.
